turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about False consensus effect.
turn.1: What is meant by the false consensus effect?
turn.2: On the other hand, someone in the same situation who makes an internal attribution (perhaps a film aficionado who is well-aware of his or her especially high standards) will realize the subjectivity of the experience and will be drawn to the opposite conclusion; their estimation of consensus with their experience will be much lower.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: Although they result in two opposite outcomes, both paths of attribution rely on an initial assumption which then leads to a "logical" conclusion.
turn.5: What is the most important aspect of this effect?
turn.6: By this logic, then, it can be said that the false-consensus effect is really a reflection of the fundamental attribution error (specifically the actor-observer bias), in which people prefer external/situational attributions over internal/dispositional ones to justify their own behaviors.
turn.7: Has further study been done on this effect?
turn.8: In a study done by Fox, Yinon, and Mayraz, researchers were attempting to determine whether or not the levels of the false-consensus effect changed in different age groups.
turn.9: What did they do in that study?
turn.10: In order to come to a conclusion, it was necessary for the researchers to split their participants into four different age groups.
turn.11: What other aspects of the study are notable?
turn.12: Two hundred participants were used, and gender was not considered to be a factor.
